MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Amendment of Holidays (Employees) Act, 1939.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if it is proposed to amend the Holidays (Employees) Act, 1939, to provide that two weeks' paid holidays instead of one week will be provided for those persons who qualify under the Act.

asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if it is proposed to introduce amending legislation to raise the income limit in respect of qualification under the provisions of the Holidays (Employees) Act, 1939.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Lemass Mr. S. Lemass
Speaker.P: I propose, with the permission of the Ceann Comhairle, to take Questions Nos. 4 and 5 together. I would refer the Deputy to the reply which I gave to a question by Deputy Norton on this subject on 12th March last. On that occasion, I indicated that in my view improvements in the conditions of employment of workers, over and above those prescribed by legislation, can be more satisfactorily arranged by the negotiation of voluntary agreements between representative organisations of employers and employees and that legislation to amend the Holidays (Employees) Act, 1938, was not at present in contemplation. I see no reason to alter this view.

Would the Minister not agree that in so far as the larger units of workers have generally enjoyed the benefits of the Holidays (Employees) Acts, because of the machinery he has mentioned, at this stage he might think it worthwhile to extend the protection of the Government and the Dáil to those employed in the smaller units where it is difficult to ensure that reasonable periods of rest are provided by trade union-employer negotiation? Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Lemass Mr. S. Lemass
Speaker.P: My view is as I have expressed it. I prefer that progress in this matter should not be made under the compulsion of legislation. If, however, it were demonstrated that there were difficulties existing of a character which only legislation could resolve, I would be prepared to consider the matter further, but with some reluctance. The evidence would have to be very conclusive that State action was essential to get the desired results.

I do not think the Minister has answered Question No. 5. Surely that is not a matter for trade union-employer negotiation? The qualification is laid down in the 1939 Act and that Act can be amended only by the Minister and the Oireachtas. Has the Minister considered the desirability of introducing a change in the legislation following upon, first of all, the increase in the cost of living over the years and, secondly, the wage adjustments which have necessarily taken place, particularly in relation to the current value of the £ as against the period referred to in the 1939 Act?

It merely means that the compulsory application of the legislation is confined to a particular class and while, no doubt, the limit fixed in the Act is now out of date, at the same time my feeling is that it is preferable that the extension of the benefit should be on the basis of voluntarily concluded negotiations.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Bon Secours Hospital, Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. MacEntee) Seán MacEntee
Speaker.P: I presume that what the Deputy has in mind is the possibility of making a grant available from the Hospitals' Trust Fund towards the capital cost incurred by the Bon Secours Order in providing a new maternity unit as an extension to their hospital.

The position in regard to a capital grant was decided some years ago. I am in full agreement with that decision. The order first applied for a grant in October, 1954. At that point I understand that planning of the new unit was being finalised and the order were hoping that building work could be undertaken shortly afterwards. The application was carefully considered in the light of the position of the Hospitals' Trust Fund at that time and other long-standing commitments in respect of the provision of maternity accommodation in the Cork area. The order were informed in December, 1954, that the position of the fund would not permit of any financial assistance being made available towards the cost of the project and that it had been decided that within the limited funds available the authorities of Erinville Hospital who had been pressing for many years for assistance to enable them to improve the very unsatisfactory accommodation in their present hospital should be assisted to provide such accommodation on the existing site.

There was never any doubt in their minds as to what the position was? They were informed well in advance and persisted in going ahead with that plan?
